title: 109_s4121
content: The curr_chunk is a section titled "TREATMENT OF LIABILITY FOR CERTAIN MULTIPLE EMPLOYER PLANS." The curr_chunk discusses the options for eligible employers regarding the liability of an applicable pension plan. If an employer elects subsection (b), the liability will be determined under that subsection. If not, it will be determined under subsection (c). Employers have 180 days to elect to spin off liability to an eligible spunoff plan. The curr_chunk discusses the treatment of an applicable pension plan as having spun off assets and liabilities to an eligible spunoff plan, with the employer's liability determined by the eligible spunoff plan. This liability will be in lieu of any other liability to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the applicable pension plan. The curr_chunk discusses the ongoing funding liability of employers electing spinoff plans, where the employer will be liable for contributions to the eligible spunoff plan until it ceases to be eligible. The employer maintaining a spinoff plan is liable for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan, following the terms of ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code. This liability replaces any other obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the applicable pension plan. This liability replaces any other obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the applicable pension plan. Interest rates are determined based on specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code for eligible spunoff plans. The employer maintaining a spinoff plan is responsible for ongoing contributions to the eligible spunoff plan as per ERISA and the Internal Revenue Code. If the plan terminates before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability resulting from the termination will apply. Interest rates for eligible spunoff plans are determined under specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code. If an applicable pension plan terminates under ERISA before December 31, 2010, the employer's liability will be determined according to specific methods and assumptions. This liability will replace any other obligations to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation or the pension plan. If an applicable pension plan is terminated under ERISA, an eligible employer not electing spinoff will be liable to the corporation for the unfunded benefit liabilities of the plan as of December 31, 2005. The adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities of a plan as of December 31, 2005, are determined without regard to any liabilities transferred to another plan. Adjusted unfunded benefit liabilities refer to the amount of unfunded liabilities with specific interest assumptions. The term "fractional portion" refers to a fraction representing the employer's contributions to a pension plan for specific plan years, compared to all employers who did not make a certain election. The term "applicable pension plan" refers to a single employer plan established in Alaska on March 18, 1967, with 2 or more contributing sponsors not under common control as of January 1, 2005. The "allocable portion" is the portion of a plan's liabilities and assets for eligible employers making an election under subsection (b). The "allocable portion" for eligible employers is the portion of an applicable pension plan's liabilities and assets that corresponds to the employer's share of the plan's excess liabilities over assets. An "eligible employer" is one that participated in an eligible multiple employer plan after January 1, 2000.
